Dear Ms. Aufdemberge:
Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the
violations identified in the report, a written corrective action plan is required. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
 How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
 Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
 Specific time frames for each violation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
 How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
 The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact
me. In any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days. Failure to submit an
acceptable corrective action plan will result in disciplinary action.
Please note that violations of any licensing rules are also violations of the MSA and your
contract.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the local office at (866) 685-0006.

ALLEGATION:
On 8/22/21, staff member was attempting to restrict youth's movements in the hall by
using their arm to block. This was described as a push. Staff members were verbally
inappropriate towards youth.
INVESTIGATION:
This complaint was transferred for investigation on 08/24/2021. The facility reported
the following to Centralized Intake:
Youth A (16) is a permanent ward who is placed at Vista Maria. Staff 1 and Staff
2 are staff members at Vista Maria. On 08/22/2021, Staff 2 was trying to restrict
Youth A’s movement in the hallways. Staff 2 used her arm to block Youth A from
going towards the doorway. Youth A said this was a push, but it was not
aggressive. Staff 2 told Keona, "No matter where you go, you will not be
successful." Staff 2 made a comment towards Youth A saying, "I can't wait to
come back to this building to take other clients out on outings and I am not taking
any disrespectful clients with me." Also, on 08/22/2021, Staff 1 was directing
Youth A to complete a chore. Youth A told Staff 1 to shut up and told her that she
would beat her ass. At some point, Youth A said to Staff 1, "You're not my mom."
Staff 1 said to Youth A, "I am not your mom, I am not trying to be your mother, I
feel sorry for your mother." It is unknown if Staff 1 is aware that Youth A’s mother
is deceased.
I interviewed Youth A at the facility on 08/26/21. Youth A reported that Staff 2 asked
her to do a chore that Youth A had already done, so Youth A began arguing with
Staff 2. Youth A said that Youth B was present. Youth A said that Staff 2 was saying
that Youth A was not going to make it when she went to her new program and that
Staff 2 couldn’t wait to come back and take kids on outings but leave Youth A there.
Youth A said that Staff 3, who is a supervisor, was also there and Youth A wanted to
talk to Staff 3. Staff 3 was leaving the area, so Youth A said that she tried to follow
her. Youth A said that Staff 1, who was also in the room, put her arm out and pushed
Youth A. Youth A said Staff 1 and Staff 2 were laughing so Youth A threw a chair at
Staff 2 because she was mad. Youth A said that Staff 3 came back in and “grabbed”
Youth A and told her to go to her room. Youth A said that she didn’t want to go. A
male staff came to the area and also told Youth A to go to her room, and Youth A
said that she was then able to walk to her room. Youth A said that Staff 3 just held
her by her arms and did not report any injuries. Youth A also reported that Staff 1
told Youth A that she’s not Youth A’s mother. Youth A denied that any staff made
any other comments about Youth A’s mother.
3

I interviewed Staff 1 at the facility. The Consumer Rights Officer (CRO) was present
for the interview with the permission of Staff 1. Staff 1 recalled the day of this
incident. Staff 1 reported that Youth A had done chores (swept floors) earlier in the
day and was then asked to resweep the floor later on. Staff 1 said that Youth A “blew
up” and yelled at Staff 1. Staff 1 said that Youth A told her that she’s not Youth A’s
mother. Staff 1 said that she replied, “I never claimed to be your mother.” Staff 1 said
that Youth A added on to that and said something like, “You know my mom’s dead,
right?” Staff 1 said that Youth A escalated from there. Staff 1 said that she
confronted Youth A on how she was changing what Staff 1 had said. Staff 1 reported
that Staff 2 and Staff 3 were present. Staff 1 denied saying anything negative about
Youth A’s mother or that she felt bad for Youth A’s mother. Staff 1 said that she did
not put hands on Youth A or restrain her. Staff 1 didn’t recall any physical contact
with Youth A. Staff 1 said that Staff 3 did end up holding Youth A as Youth A
escalated and then walked her off to her room.
A conference call was held with involved parties to Youth A’s case, including Youth
A’s worker, and the Placement Collaboration Unit, on 08/30/21. The complaint and
updates were provided and discussed.
I interviewed Youth B at school on 09/21/21. Youth B said that she did not hear any
staff make comments about Youth A’s mother. Youth B said that she did hear a staff
say, “I’m not trying to be your mom” in response to Youth A saying, “You’re not my
mom.” Youth B denied hearing any staff say any negative comments like in the
allegations.
I interviewed Staff 3 at the school on 09/21/21. The Consumer Rights Officer (CRO)
was present for the interview with the permission of Staff 3. Staff 3 reported that
Youth A was upset over chores and Youth B ended up doing the sweeping. Staff 1
and Staff 2 were reportedly redirecting Youth A, as was Staff 3. Staff 3 said that she
also reminded Youth A of upcoming rewards for chores and proceeded to leave the
room. After leaving, Staff 3 said that she heard a noise and went back in to find
Youth A threw a chair at staff. Staff 3 said that Staff 1 put her arm out to stop Youth
A from going toward the door. Staff 3 said she held Youth A, “not restrained, just
held her back.” Staff 3 said Youth A was not struggling. A male staff came to assist,
and they talked to Youth A before walking her to her room. Staff 3 said Youth A
walked on her own and noted her room was just outside the living area where the
incident occurred. Staff 3 said that she held Youth A by her arms because she was
not calm enough to let her go and she felt she couldn’t let her go until she was
calmed down. Staff 3 confirmed that the facility uses the Crisis Prevention Institute
(CPI) model for restraint and that she is not supposed to hold a youth by herself.
Staff 3 again said that she was not “restraining” Youth A, but just “holding her back.”
Staff 3 denied saying or hearing any other staff say things like Youth A would be
unsuccessful when she left the program. Staff 3 reported that Youth A told Staff 1
she’s not her mother, and Staff 1 responded by saying that she was not trying to be
her mother. Staff 3 denied saying, or hearing any staff say that they felt sorry for
Youth A’s mother.
4

I interviewed Staff 2 via phone, on 09/21/2, with the CRO was present. Staff 2
reported a consistent account of what occurred, as reported by the other staff. Staff
2 said that she did hear Staff 1 say something like she didn’t claim to be Youth A’s
mother. Staff 2 said that Youth A responded to Staff 1 by saying something like,
“How could you say that when my mom is dead.” Staff 2 said that Youth A and Staff
1 then argued back and forth. Staff 2 said that Staff 3 was leaving the area and Staff
2 went to close the door, when Youth A threw a chair at her. Staff 3 came back in
and gave Youth A a sort of hug to get Youth A to calm down. Staff 1 called for
assistance and the male staff came. Youth A then deescalated and walked to her
room. Staff 2 denied saying or hearing any staff make the remarks from the
allegations, such as, not taking Youth A on outings, Youth A not being successful, or
comments about feeling sorry for Youth A’s mother.
During this investigation, the CRO stated in email and conversation that he had
already done some coaching with Staff 3 related to her holding Youth A in the
manner she did. Per the CRO, even though it seems Staff 3 held Youth A out
concern of the present risk at the time, that single person hold is not provided for in
the CPI techniques taught at the facility. The CRO also confirmed that neither Staff 1
nor Staff 3 have any related disciplinary action in their employee files. The CRO
reported that Staff 2 “did have a disciplinary action for unprofessional demeanor
when a client threw a pencil sharpener in January of 2021. This was the only I saw
in her file in relation to this type of behavior.”
A review of the video of this incident showed the following:
The video starts at 1:23.22 with a view of the living area where Youth A was seated
on the windowsill, Youth B was sweeping, and Staffs 1, 2, and 3 were in the area.
Staff 3 left the area and Staff 2 was about to close the door when Youth A got up
and went toward the door. Staff 2 closed the door and Youth A grabbed a chair and
threw it at Staff 2. Staff 1 approached Youth A, who backed up, and Staff 3 came
back in the room. Youth A went to walk toward the door and at about 1:25:08, Staff 1
put her arm out in front of Youth A. Youth A grabbed on to Staff 1’s arm and then
pushed Staff 1 away from her. Youth A lost her balance as she tried to kick Staff 1
and fell to her knees, catching herself on a table. Youth A got up and started walking
toward Staff 1, who was backing away from the youth. Staff 3 walked behind Youth
A and at about 1:25:16, held Youth A by her arms/bicep area. Youth A struggled a
little bit with Staff 3, but not excessively. Staff 2 approached and appeared to be
assisting, but Youth A jerked her hands away from Staff 2. Staff 3 turned Youth A
away from Staff 1 and continued to hold her arms. Staff 1 and Staff 2 continue to
move about the area. Staff 3 holds Youth A standing near the wall. Staff 1 returned
to talk to Youth A, which appeared to agitate Youth A. Staff 1 walked back out of
Youth A’s line of sight. At about 1:31:18, a male staff entered the area and talked to
Youth A. Staff 3 continued holding Youth A by the arms, but Youth A was not
struggling with her. When Staff 1 approached Youth A again, at about 1:31:38,
Youth A swung around and was again held back by Staff 3. The male staff and Staff
2 stepped between Youth A and Staff 1. Staff 1 continued talking to Youth A, which
5

appeared to agitate Youth A. Staff 1 walked away and the other staff continued to
talk to Youth A. Staff 3 continued to hold her arms. Staff 3 then walked forward to
prompt Youth A to walk. They stop and talk for a bit and then slowly walk off camera
with Staff 3 still holding Youth A’s arms at about 1:33:21.
APPLICABLE RULE
R 400.158 Discipline.
(2) An institution shall prohibit all cruel and severe
discipline, including any of the following:
(a) Any type of corporal punishment inflicted in any
manner.
(c) Verbal abuse, ridicule, or humiliation.
ANALYSIS: The facility is compliant with the rule. There was no pushing
observed on the video review. The staff put her arm out in front
of Youth A, in an attempt to stop her from going to the door.
Youth A’s response was escalated and her attempt to push
away from the staff and kick staff appeared to be what caused
her to fall. There was also no support of the allegations of verbal
abuse/ridiculing comments by staff.
CONCLUSION: VIOLATION NOT ESTABLISHED
ADDITIONAL FINDINGS:
The facility did not follow their physical management model.
INVESTIGATION:
During the course of this investigation, a review of the video was completed, and it
was observed that Staff 3 held Youth A by her arms/bicep area. This action is not
provided for under the facility’s physical management model, CPI.
6

APPLICABLE RULE
R 400.4159 Resident restraint.
(1) An institution shall establish and follow written policies
and procedures regarding restraint. These policies and
procedures shall be available to all residents, their families,
and referring agencies.
ANALYSIS: The facility is in violation of the rule as the act of one staff
holding the youth from behind by the youth’s arms/bicep area is
not a technique provided for in the facility’s approved restraint
model, CPI. CPI requires a two person hold and with each staff
securing one arm. It should be noted that this restraint was not
egregious in any manner and did not appear to require the use
of much force to secure the youth, however, the staff must
follow the approved methods outlined in their policies.
CONCLUSION: VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on the findings of this investigation, I recommend no change to the current
license status. This recommendation is contingent on the facility submitting an
acceptable corrective action plan for the noted violations.

sir_summary.summary: The investigation found that while the specific allegations of staff pushing a youth and making verbally abusive comments were not substantiated by video evidence or witness accounts, a violation was established because a staff member improperly restrained a youth by using a single-person hold not permitted under the facility's approved Crisis Prevention Institute (CPI) physical management model. The facility was found non-compliant with restraint policies and is required to submit a corrective action plan. The report concludes that the facility, not an individual staff member, is culpable for the policy violation related to improper restraint technique.

sir_violation_level.justification: The substantiated violation involved the use of a physical restraint technique (a single staff member holding a youth by the arms/bicep area) that was not part of the facility's approved Crisis Prevention Institute (CPI) model. This falls under the 'Restraint and seclusion' category for severe SIRs, as it represents an incident suggesting excessive force or unsafe de-escalation practices due to the deviation from the approved safety model.
